history.content:
Short answer: You don't really need to take math 53. Strong background in linear algebra is the most important. Partial derivatives, gradients, Hessians, and some exposure to Lagrange multiples are all you need from math 53.

Long answer: This really depends on your mathematical maturity. Optimization for most people is a completely new topic. The main idea of optimization is not just about setting the derivative of a multivariable function to 0 or doing some advanced matrix manipulations. Optimization is about convex analysis and duality. Surprisingly, despite its importance, convexity is rarely mentioned in most lower divs (even in the math department, there are no undergrad courses on convex analysis solely). Duality appears in many fields (physics, economics, control, etc.) but is never explicitly taught (e.g. momentum is the Lagrange multiplier of the position, and the transpose of a matrix is an operation on the dual vector space). So, unless you knew some optimization theory already, there will be some hard concepts in 127. The good news is that the EECS department is trying to incorporate linear algebra into a lot of courses, and eecs16a/b are examples demonstrating this trend. In 127, the first month will be devoted to a review of linear algebra, so having a strong understanding of linear algebra will be crucial to earning a good grade.

Most topics (such as divergence, curl, line integrals, and surface integrals) in math 53 are pretty much useless if you are not going to take any physics-related courses (electromagnetism, quantum mechanics, etc.). Lots of students think that math 53 is about learning how to do partial derivatives or multiple integrals, but, to be honest, you can learn those topics in 1 day by yourself because they are simple generalizations of the 1D cases. Here is my personal opinion: After taking math 53, if you don't understand the divergence theorem and stoke's theorem in an intuitive way, then you have largely wasted your time. Moreover, if you are not interested in electromagnetism, which is where those things come from, you won't have the chance to apply what you learn from math 53. 

Again, to get an A/A+, you really need to be good at linear algebra (both conceptually and computationally). Based on my own experience, if you are super good at linear algebra, you shouldn't need to spend more than 5 hours each week outside the class (the 5 hours are mainly for the homework).

Long answer: This really depends on your mathematical maturity. Optimization for most people is a completely new topic. The main idea of optimization is not just about setting the derivative of a multivariable function to 0 or doing some advanced matrix manipulations. Optimization is about convex analysis and duality. Most topics (such as divergence, curl, line integrals, and surface integrals) in math 53 are pretty much useless if you are going to take any physics-related courses (electromagnetism, quantum mechanics, etc.). Lots of students think that math 53 is about learning how to do partial derivatives or multiple integrals, but, to be honest, you can learn those topics in 1 day by yourself because they are simple generalizations of the 1D cases. Here is my personal opinion: After taking math 53, if you don't understand the divergence theorem and stoke's theorem in an intuitive way, then you have largely wasted your time. Moreover, if you are not interested in electromagnetism, which is where those things come from, you won't have the chance to apply what you learn from math 53.

children.subject:
There are several ways I build up my linear algebra intuition:

1. Take Math 110 and learn the abstract theory about vector space. Note that the amount of knowledge you take away from math110 largely depends on how you learn math. Try to focus more abstract things presented in math110 because those things can take your further in almost any subfield of EE and CS. Linear algebra is not about matrix manipulation; in fact, you should be able to talk about all the concepts (except determinants) in linear algebra without referring to matrices.

2. Learn through the application. Honestly, this depends on your interests. Personally, I learn more linear algebra from Fourier analysis (EE120), physics (Physics 137A/B), and control (EE128, EE221A or ME232). Your intuition increases gradually and in unintentional ways, which makes mathematical maturity a hard thing to train. If optimization and its related fields (ML, optimal control, etc) are what you want to pursue, I would also recommend math170, which goes in parallel with 127 and gives rigorous proof to everything in 127. Math170 also introduces some calculus of variations and optimal control theory.

3. I strongly recommend Gilbert Strang's video on linear algebra (18.06 https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLE7DDD91010BC51F8). Stephen Boyd's video on linear dynamical systems (https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL06960BA52D0DB32B) also has some good material if you want to see things a little bit beyond eecs16b. He is the coauthor who wrote Convex Optimization (https://web.stanford.edu/~boyd/cvxbook/bv_cvxbook.pdf), a book you should definitely read if you seriously want to enter the field.

Regarding 1, there is a way to define the determinant of a linear transformation without matrices - it's covered in Math H110 (which is a really cool class that I definitely recommend, although it's also quite a bit of work)
@Anonymous Mouse: in addition to taking 16a/16b, what are some good ways to increase our linear algebra intuition? Any particular classes/books/videos?

history.content:
I'm a current freshman planning out my fall schedule, and by this fall I will have taken all of 16a, 16b, and 70, but not math 53. I was wondering how necessary math 53 is to succeed in 127. If its possible to pick up the math 53 related concepts as I go, which particular concepts are most relevant to 127?

Thanks!
history.subject: Necessity of Math 53 for 127
